headline: Rhubarb Sour Cream Pie
description: This is a favorite in our house during rhubarb season. My husband who doesn't care much for rhubarb loves this pie. It has a creamy sweet tart tang.
name: Rhubarb Sour Cream Pie

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 450 degrees F (220 degrees C).

Press the pie crust into a 9 inch pie pan. Spread rhubarb in an even layer in the bottom of the crust. In a medium bowl, whisk together the egg, white sugar, sour cream and 1/3 cup of flour until smooth. Pour over the rhubarb.
In a small bowl, mix together 1/2 cup of flour and brown sugar. Stir in melted butter until the mixture is crumbly. Sprinkle over the top of the pie.

Bake for 15 minutes in the preheated oven, then reduce the heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Continue to bake for 40 minutes, or until the edges have puffed, and the topping is golden. The center may still be slightly jiggly. Cool completely before slicing and serving.

review.reviewBody: I loved the flavour of this rhubarb. I put only 1 cup of sugar for the rhubarb. However, I found it very gummy as I must cook with gluten free flour which doesn't end up anything like wheat flour. I thought, maybe another beaten egg, cut back on the gluten free flour and add more tapioca flour to thicken. Any ideas?? Anyone??
I loved it so much! It is super easy to make and love every time I have it. It has been a family favorite for long time.

Absolutely fabulous as written. Important notes: this is a big pie, ideally you would use a 9 inch deep dish pie plate. It will not fit into a pre-made freezer crust that’s already in a tray (even the “deep dish” one). You also must use fresh rhubarb (or it will be too watery) and you must use FULL-Fat sour cream. The sour cream mixture also must be mixed really really well or you’ll have clumps. Also, Although great as written, I prefer a crumb topping with oats. Also don’t open the oven when you turn the temp down and it does need the full 55 minutes.

I use this as a very solid base recipe, with only a few changes: Half or less sugar in the sour cream mixture, For the crumble I add half a cup of rolled oats & double the butter & brown sugar, making a double portion of crumble. We find that the rhubarb maintains more rhubarb flavor & the crumble contributes the sweetness. Also, we find that this pie is best refrigerated overnight before eating. For whatever reason, refrigeration increases the rhubarb flavor & sort of “cures” the pie into a heavenly delight. Everyone loves it.
This is the hands-down favourite pie in our house! Perfect sweet-tangy taste! Frozen rhubarb works just as well for a taste of summer in the dead of winter. Yum!

Delicious and irresistible. Have made several, to rave reviews. Crusty topping "makes" the pie and is very easy. 
Added some quartered strawberries, about 1/4 of the quantity of rhubarb. 
Used plain non-fat Greek yogurt instead of sour cream to lower the fat content with no impact on the flavor.

This is the second time I’ve made this. I cut the sugar in half and will reduce it again next time. The first time I made it, It spilled over the edges of the 9” pie plate and made a horrible mess in the oven. This time, I added 1 tbsp of tapioca to help absorb juice, and used a 10” pie plate. Voila! The pie stayed in the pie plate where it belongs.

My wife is cranking on a paper so I volunteered to be supportive this morning. Made Brunch.
Used "Grandma's Secret Pie Crust."
Used Allspice instead of cinnamon on top.
When asked if she liked it, our 8-year-old put her finger on her lips and said, "Shhhh."
Definite keeper.
This recipe is a family favourite. Very easy. Everyone loves this pie.

When I make this again I will use less sugar as the sweetness overpowered the tartness as others have mentioned. I think 3/4-1cp would work better. Very happy with this recipe...enjoy

Will definitely try this recipe again but halve the sugar. Very sweet and overpowers the rhubarb (I also wonder if the sour cream mellows the rhubarb too?). I skipped the crumb topping and went for a loose lattice crust instead which I would do again.
The pie is sweet tart creamy. I love the crunch of the crumb topping! This is a winner.

We love this recipe at my house! Make it at least once a week all May (while the rhubarb is fresh). I usually also add oats to the top crumble and it pairs really well (and helps me pretend it's healthy ;))
This is by the best rhubarb pie I've ever had or made. No changes. Perfect as is. Rhubarb is in season now so this is my go to rhubarb pie now. Amazing!!!
Awesome! It wasn’t enough filling so I increased the rhubarb but kept the sugar at the same and it was just fine.?

My whole family loved this pie, I would make it again.

I have made this pie at least 2 dozen times. It is my favorite rhubarb dessert. These adjustments work for my tastes: I use 1 cup plus 2 tbsp. sugar instead of 1 1/2 cup. I add an additional 1 tbsp. flour to the 1/3 cup for the filling. I add 1 tsp. cinnamon to the streusel topping. I bake a bit longer than stated (sorry I don't know exactly how long but at least an additional 5 minutes). The additional flour and additional bake time gives the interior a firmer, more cheesecake-like interior. I always cover it loosely with aluminum foil near the end to keep the top from getting too brown with the additional bake time.

fantastic!!

Loved the recipe, sweet yet tart. I will make it again with a deep dish pie shell.

This is absolutely amazing. There was too much filling for a 9" deep dish store bought crust. I did add zest from one orange and a tablespoon of the juice just because I like that rhubarb/orange flavor blend. Wow so tasty and easy. Next time I want to do what other reviewers suggest and double this with a graham crust in a 9x13 pan. Thank you for this awesome recipe.

Yum yum yum. What eles can be said.
My family loved this. It's a keeper.

This was excellent! Hubby and friends have asked me to make it again. I did cut the sugar back to 1 cup. The volume of ingredients was off a bit so I might adjust that next time but the taste was amazing. I used a deep dish pie shell and only needed about 3 cups of rhubarb. Also, the sour creme mixture over the 3 cups of rhubarb filled it right to be brim so that it spilled over while cooking. That was ok because it made the crust chewy and yummy, but when I took it out of the oven there was a huge air bubble in the middle that collapsed when it cooled. All of that was perfectly fine for my home pie, but if I was taking it somewhere I would use a little less filling to make a better presentation. Will definitely make this lots!
Excellent recipe. I have also made it with blueberries. In both recipes I added cinnamon

That is why we only gave it a 4 star.
this was quite sweet and quite tat. I really liked it. not sure about my husband yet.

Had to do some tweaking, but it was delicious. My pie plates were not deep enough so divided up the rhubarb between 2 pies. Also substituted all sugar with raw brown sugar (also reduced the amount by 1/3.

I’m making it for the 3rd time in the last month. Today it is with fresh rhubarb (rather than frozen from last summer). I have followed the recipe exactly but now I reduce the sugar to 1 cup which is plenty. Also, I have added 2 cups of fresh strawberries without reducing the rhubarb. I've made this pie over and over and over. A local baker makes an amazing strawberry rhubarb sour cream pie so I came onto Allrecipes to find something similar. This recipe has become a favourite with my family and my coworkers. Sometimes I use 2 cups of rhubarb and 2 cups of strawberries and since the berries are so sweet, I cut back on the sugar to 1 cup. I have a favourite crumble recipe that I use as a modification to this one - 1/4 c brown sugar, 1/4 c flour, 1/4 c oats, 1/4 c melted butter. The oats add a bit of crunchiness to the topping. I also find that for a standard pie tin, this recipe will make two whole pies if you just add 1/2 c more of the rhubarb.
Awesome pie! I used plain Greek yogurt instead of sour cream and it was amazing!
So so good!! But I doubled the recipe and should have filled three pie shells. Had to bake extra 15 minutes and pies were overflowing. But 5 stars for flavor and ease!

This is so delicious!! I love it cold with whipped cream on top! I will stick with this recipe!

YUMMY-YUMMY in the tummy! Even family who claimed to hate rhubarb LOVED this pie. I did add cinnamon & nutmeg to the filling and topping and that was the only change/addition I made. Try it...You'll love it!
Delicious! I would highly recommend this recipe. It was a bit sweet, so next time I'll reduce the sugar in the sour cream mixture.
I found this to be too much filling for one pie. It was very sweet, almost too sweet.

This was a wonderful recipe. I'm just glad that pie shells are sold in two's because there was enough filling and topping for two magnificent pies. I added cinnamon to the custard mix and might add a bit of vanilla next time...and there WILL be a next time!

My family went bazerk over this! It tastes just like a more complicated pie my grandma used to make. Now the relatives are requesting it for every gathering! Made this pie exactly as written and it turned out terrible .It had the consistantcy of paste. Did not have much rhubarb taste. Pie went into the garbage. Could not eat. Obviously will not make again!

I think this is the best pie I've ever made! I must free up some freezer space and get busy to assure availability of rhubarb all year around. The only modification to the recipe I made was to add a bit more rhubarb (I used about 6 cups instead of 4).

OMG! This pie is awesome. Mine looks less attractive, but is definitely one of the best pies I've ever done or had. I use Paula Deen's recipe for pie crust and just replaced sour cream with thick natural yoghurt. Fabulous.

So easy to make and a beautiful presentation.......but sour cream.......not so much.

I made some changes due to lack of ingredients (used just dark muscovado for anything requiring sugar, and wholewheat flour for the white flour).
Despite the shortcomings, the resulting pie was quite tasty.
I give it 5 stars as it seems to be a fool proof recipe ;) Trust me.
This pie should have 10 stars. It is great!

Excellent pie! My all-time favorite rhubarb pie is the rhubarb custard from the 1950's Betty Crocker cookbook. This one is different, but is much easier, and also tastes great!

I used closer to 5 cups of rhubarb (which fit nicely into a 10 inch pie plate), then followed the rest of the recipe as written. The recipe says to wait until it cools to cut and eat it, but of course warm pie is awesome, so we had a piece before it cooled completely. It was good, but the sour cream was the predominant flavor. Once it had cooled overnight, the sour cream flavor was much less evident, and the rhubarb flavor shone through.

The topping is a nice addition and is much lighter than some desserts. It was nice and crisp and delicious! I have 4 rhubarb plants and am always looking for good recipes. This one is definitely a keeper!
This is a fantastic recipe...I have been making it for years, but mine recipe calls for 3 cups rhubarb and in the topping I add grated orange rind. Love this recipe.
Excellent!
Amazing!!!! Next time I'll add more rhubarb, but it was fantastic! And gone in a flash!!!!
I deleted 1/2 cup of the white sugar because we are not "sweet" eaters. It was great, we both went back for seconds. Making it again tonight

I followed the recipe exactly as written using thawed frozen rhubarb and the pie was absolutely delicious! My kids had never had rhubarb before and weren't sure what to expect, but loved it. And, it was really easy to make too. I will definitely make this again.

My husband loves rhubarb pie and so I was hesitant to try something other than the standard pie recipe, but I made this yesterday and he LOVED it. I've been instructed to replace my old recipe with this one. I only made one slight change and used about 1/4 less sugar.
Wow-sooo good! This is a definite keeper, & easy is an extra bonus! This will be my go to summer pie from now on-thanks for sharing!

A.maz.ing!

The only thing I will likely do next time is to prebake the crust a bit before adding the ingredients.
